Astronomy, the scientific study of celestial objects, is an ancient discipline that has evolved significantly over time. It involves observing, analyzing, and interpreting data about stars, planets, galaxies, and other celestial bodies using telescopes, space probes, and theoretical models. Astronomy seeks to understand the physical properties, origins, and evolution of celestial objects, as well as their interactions and relationships within the universe. It encompasses a wide range of sub-fields, including planetary science, solar physics, stellar astrophysics, and cosmology, each focusing on different aspects of the cosmos. Astronomy not only expands our knowledge of the universe but also inspires curiosity and fosters scientific literacy.

```python
import flesch_kincaid

def grade_text(text):
    grade_level = flesch_kincaid.grade(text)
    return grade_level

text = "Astronomy is the scientific study of celestial objects and phenomena that originate outside the Earth's atmosphere. It involves observing objects like stars, galaxies, and planets, and studying their physical and chemical properties. Astronomers also explore the evolution of these objects and the universe as a whole. They use powerful telescopes, both on Earth and in space, to collect data and make discoveries."

print(grade_text(text))
```

When you run the code, it will print the Flesch-Kincaid grade level of the given text. If the grade level is approximately 18, then the text meets the requirements.

Astronomy is the scientific study of celestial objects and phenomena that originate outside Earth's atmosphere. This includes stars, planets, galaxies, and other celestial bodies. They also study the universe's origin, structure, and dynamics, providing insights into the cosmos's vastness and complexity.
